p: It has been proven that without proper enforcement heat regulations are likely to pose little restrictions to non-compliant employers [ 39, 40]. In 2010, California became the first State in the USA to enact a stringent heat-specific law to protect workers from heat exposure [ 41]. Two years later however, inspectors found that more than half of the employers they audited did not comply with the heat standard [ 42]. Heat prevention measures seem straightforward, common-sense, and simple (e.g., drinking water frequently, wearing light coloured and permeable clothes, taking breaks in the shade, and responding to early symptoms). However, a variety of factors at multiple levels in the workplace may constrain such implementation, such as production quotas, worries of being considered ‘soft’, and workers’ fears of losing their job [ 11, 21, 39]. Currently, there is no federal occupational standard specifically addressing heat illness and injury prevention in Australia [ 12, 35], which may make the implementation of heat prevention measures problematic.
